comments.commentBody: Paul, thanks for your compliments, and I agree that statistics are unreliable indicators for a game where a single instant of brilliance can change the outcome, and where who's on form can be so important, and where individual team matchups can run counter to the statistics.  I'm just having fun, trying to see if there's a better way to predict outcomes based on prior results (recent ones, so that issues of form might be accounted for).  I realize this post partially repeats a couple of my earlier ones, but I wanted to put the entire list of 16 out there -- for your amusement, if nobody else's!

Certainly agree re: Brazil's chances v. Colombia. But really one could have made that prediction about Brazil before the Cup. Of course you could argue (as I did) that without Falcao Colombia wouldn't quite have the horsepower to keep up with the favorites. And certainly Oscar can do better than he has. But anybody expecting anything but plodsmanship (much less moments of genius) out of the Paulinhos and Freds and Ramireses that Big Phil has stocked his side with has got to be completely mad.

On topic: goal of the match for me so far. Will take some beating.

Rodriguez' goal is one of the three best in the tournament, with Van Persie's diving header v. Spain and Tim Cahill's first time volley against Holland.

Based on today's performances, I give Colombia a good chance to eliminate Brazil. Other than Neymar, who was excellent, no Brazilian player played to potential, including Julio Cesar who, although he saved two penalties, should have done better on Sanchez' equalizer, and was left rooted by Pinilla's shot that crashed the crossbar in the 120th minute and came within inches of descending Brazil into despair.
In particular, Brazil has been dependent on Dani Alves and Marcelo to carry the ball upfield and provide service. In the match v Uruguay, Armero and Zuniga for Colombia were far superior to their Brazilian counterparts v Chile. If this form holds for the QF, it bodes very badly for Brazil.
Many of the speeches by prominent public personages end with "God bless America." With the politics of government of, by, and for the wealthy,   they should say "God help America. "
Um, Neymar was, by a very wide margin, Brazil's best player today, and the only one who was dangerous whenever he was on the ball.

The replays pretty clearly showed Officer Krupke made the right call in disallowing Hulk's goal. There were penalty shouts on both sides, in which the Yorkshire cop showed little interest.
Brazil should count itself very fortunate that Pinilla's shot in the 120th minute slammed the bar and did not go in.
As for the calls going against Brazil, Julio Cesar was two steps off the line on the first Chilean penalty, and Webb let the save stand.

It was a hand ball by any interpretation of the rules. As for the officiating overall, the ref clearly allowed both teams to "stretch their legs" a bit.  Both got away with fouls and the officiating did not decide this game. Chile overall were the most engaged team and therefore perhaps more deserving to win. But Cesar's penalty save wad magnificent and in the end I'm happy that the great host nation survives for another round. But we saw little today that suggests Brazil is on its way to number 6. (Although Hulk exhibited a tremendous work effort.) I think Colombia will provide you a very serious challenge.

NBA teams would have to play NINE overtimes just to get to regulation football match length (including 3 minutes of injury time, which is low for two halves). They'd have to get to FIFTEEN overtimes to reach an extra time match. Even with all the timeouts, and don't forget the TV timeouts, having NBA teams settle things in a free throw contest AFTER playing 15 overtime periods would probably not end well, either.

Thank you. It is unbelievable how the blogosphere is burning with the "referee sided with Chile" nonsense --- this from Brazilian fans who see themselves as experts in understanding the game. Hulk directed his bicep to the ball --- how difficult is that for some folks to understand? " An English referee conspiracy" is my other favorite line.  Enough please! Accept the narrow win graciously and get prepared because Jamie Rodriguez is coming...

@rb: What you fail to appreciate is that the shootout only occurs *after* the teams have played overtime, 1/3 the duration of the regulation match (that would be 16 minutes for NBA basketball, not five, 13.33 minutes for college basketball, not five. Lacrosse would be 20 minutes instead of four minutes.

I live on Pine Ridge Indian Reservation which takes up the whole of Shannon county, South Dakota and the tribe here is /was the most Democratic voting bloc in all of the U.S., 93.4 %. So the statement that Native Americans are not well understood and vote either way doesn't really figure!
Native Americans have been fooled by the US for centuries? SO it follows that ..."they won't be fooled by a paleface...?"  John you need to re evaluate your comment... it doesn't make any sense.
good call.  Conservatives rarely make any sense.

I'm sure that the great Native American senator, Elizabeth Warren, will be prominent in the campaign for Native American votes. How can they turn her down when she is 1/64 Native American? Answer: easy.
Native Americans have been fooled by the US for centuries. They won't be fooled by a paleface masquerading as a Native American.

Senator Begich (D) and Congressman Don Young (R) both agree to abide by the decision made by Alaskan voters on the marijuana legalization initiative.

As to how it affects Native communities in rural Alaska, it's difficult to say. Even if pot is legalized here, many bush villages may elect to remain "dry," as some have done with alcohol. That's up to individual village councils.

I lived in a remote dry village for many years and saw first hand that the alcohol prohibition didn't work. People still rode for hours upriver to get a bottle from "wet" villages, or had it smuggled in on planes. The same thing has been going on for years with all kinds of drugs, including marijuana. If you want it badly enough, you have already figured out how to get it in even the most remote areas of the state.

If pot is legalized by Alaska voters I doubt it will change the rate of consumption for Natives or anyone else.
The Democrats are all for "diversity" so long as you don't argue with their machine.  For instance, where is the diversity in the candidates running for the 2016 presidential nomination.

You can also file a complaint on the VA's website and request an answer in writing by the director of the VA hospital - that way there is a documented paper trail and the director can never say the problem was not brought to his/her attention.

Never had to use the VA until I hit my 50's. As far as the VA in Long Beach, Ca. No major complaints here, and when I do have a problem not shy about  running to the Patients Advocates Office and letting them know what I think...LOUDLY.
Taking good care.
I'm sure that John, Esq will be both talking and taking good care of Mrs. John.
Mrs. John is supposed to stay off her feet and elevate her broken one. That's like telling a mime to speak.

Martin, I’ve had a long day. Last night the wife fell. At first she seemed okay. But this morning she woke up with her foot swollen and bruised. I insisted she get it x-rayed. We hate the ER. In the last year Northwestern has opened up immediate care centers around Chicago. They require no appointment. So we went to one this morning. It was paradise compared to the ER. After a 40 minute wait (compared to a three hour ER wait) they took her in and the physician’s assistant ordered an x-ray. The knee was not serious. While I was waiting I watched Showtime’s Alex cross on my cell phone. We went up the elevator a couple of floors and she was x-rayed. When she came out she was in a wheelchair. I said that was an upgrade. She went in walking and came out riding. On the elevator back to the PA I reminded her that she wanted new shoes.We left with her wearing a boot that was black matching her other shoe. The fifth metatarsal had a simple fracture.

Then the son is taking care of the kid and wanted to play golf. Originally we were first going to visit the cemetery where the wife’s parents are buried but that went out with the boot. We played 9 holes in 90 degree heat. Afterward I took them to P.F. Chang’s where the gin and tonics are better than the Kung Pao chicken. The place was packed and it took an hour just to get seated. By that time I had downed my G&T and was working on my Kettel One.

Got home around 10:30, took a shower and am now winding down.

See you tomorrow.
same old story just different war and generation.

Most of the inexperience is because the most experienced medical teams are needed in the war zones and Germany. During times when there isn't an active war, you will find that the medical care at base medical centers & hospitals is drastically improved.

'During times when there isn't an active war...' I don't understand. What does this mean? I though we always have an active war. But then, I am only fifteen years old, and we don't spend a lot of time on history in school.
That's totally untrue, Gorgegirl. The youngest doctors and corpsmen deploy with infantry units. Specialists and other senior folks are typically hospital staff and tend to remain in place.

Tricare, the military's insurance, is excellent. I left the Marine Corps in 2011 and now have health care through a Silicon Valley tech giant. Tricare was better insurance.

The only trick was to choose the options that never required you to see a military doctor at military facilities. The quality is at best uneven and often flat bad. Doctors and nurses are typically very young and inexperienced -- junior officers and enlistees. They're not below average because they're stupid or negligent, they just need seasoning. Senior medical staff, like the rest of the military hierarchy, aren't the best of the best, they're the ones who decided to stay. It's no way to create excellent care.

Residing in Midwest, but referring to Westchester as home base for kids' high school. I no dinna get it. I'm two years shy of my 50th reunion from a small liberal arts college in New Haven, and it only went co-ed after I graduated. We put up our weekend dates in the Taft Hotel. My alumni mag had a cover article about this problem within the last 18 months. The article mentioned a chant from a from members (pledges?) of a fraternity that like all others, is 'off-campus'.  The basic idea of the chant was that "consent" on the part of the woman involved, was NOT an issue. For once, I think Mr. D. has ideas that merit serious consideration.
Living in a perfect Westchester town must have been wonderful, especially with the Clinton's for neighbors.  Give me a break.

Or, monitor fraternity parties somehow.  During the '90's, my sons attending Rutgers, had the good sense to avoid the drunks there and to advise girlfriends to do the same.  None of the kids from our  Westchester town--with its diverse student population and high standards--joined fraternities or sororities.  Spontaneously:  they would not discriminate vs their high school friends.  No adults influenced them, amazingly enough.

Are we reading the same column? I didn't see any of those sentiments expressed by Douthat in this column. At least quote the relevant section, if you don't want to come across as putting words in his mouth.

Students want freedom and, conversely, protection, and simultaneously fail to assume responsibility. Yes, we *should* all behave in gentle and kind ways and respect each other's boundaries. People *should* be able to roam campus and the streets scantily clad or dance in ways that simulate sex acts and not be assaulted. But the realities are other and we all need to adhere to practices to reduce risk.

As part of the maturation process, students must assume responsibility and not engage in behavior that can be misinterpreted (i.e. inviting or going with someone to a private place or room); they must refrain from becoming intoxicated (no, it's not far fetched); ensure that they are always accompanied, guard each other's beverages, and look out for one another. These practices, along with high community standards and educational programs, would go a long way to reducing the number of assaults on campus.

Those are 3 smart points, Ross, thank you. I'd offer:

What about scare tactics? As part of freshman orientation, have video presentations by the DEA, local law enforcement, inmates, victims of rape etc.-- like the new anti-smoking ads, over-the-top and unsparing in imagery & horror. Drill in their (most often male) heads the zero tolerance policy of the DA & the university.

In fact, make every administrator, fat cat donor, sports booster, endowment chair, and any & every heavyweight affiliate of the university participate too. Maybe they'll second guess cosseting their private equity golf buddy's frat son or the star tight end.
How many houses use manufactured joists and what adhesives are you referring, too?
What sort of advantages do the wood sheet goods have over regular wood are they more resistant to termites, stronger?

As a long time "craftsman"  contractor, now in my final years as a actual working tradesman in the residential trades, and having built and renovated a varied quality of homes- from the multi million dollars homes of the wealthy to your everyday "cape" style house let me make a couple of observations. The out- gassing from the adhesives to make structural components like manufactured joists, pressed wood sheet goods, etc. is persistent problem, If I were building my own house, I'd avoid them, and in a new house I'd let it breath for a couple of months before I lived there. Build the house out of regular dimensional lumber,  even if it's not as fine grained of yesteryear, as the farmed stuff of today.  You won't get as wide open spans as what the manufacturers and the code allows but who knows if this stuff will last, and it will burn like the dickens. Another observation is that architects make nice drawings but hardly speak to trades people.

Kudos Mr Douthat. Your first suggestion was excellent, and I never expected to hear a social conservative propose it. Your second & third suggestions though, seem awkward & overly like a police-state. Colleges are a vital grooming place that prepare teenagers for adult life in the real world, and this requires giving them the freedom to live their own lives & make their own decisions.

I think you're overlooking one additional step that could be taken though. Educating incoming freshmen on safely enjoying the campus nightlife. Creating an environment where people speak out when they witness something happening. Creating channels that allow victims to report what happened, with peace of mind.

This is a major problem that needs addressing, regardless of politics or ideology. We may not get the perfect solution immediately, but only by taking measures & seeing what works, can we start finding the answer.

www.outlookzen.com

First thing, after George Will, what an enormous relief it is to hear a conservative take college rape seriously. I'm a liberal but I feel better now.

Second thing, as long as we're talking about reducing the drinking age to 18, let's talk about legalizing marijuana. Now the mere existence of marijuana has not eliminated the abuse of alcohol. Obviously. But a lot of those students are drinking because they want to relax and they can't get pot.

The universities practice zero tolerance on marijuana and the federal government will take away their financial aid if they get caught with any and get arrested.

The Bush administration tried its best to create the impression that marijuana is a college date rape drug. They funded a public service campaign that showed two college students conspiring to rape a girl passed out on marijuana. But everyone knows marijuana is not a date rape drug. It doesn't make someone pass out. It doesn't render its users completely unconscious.

Those ads were just snickered at until they were removed.

There is relaxed culture in the cannabis world. When alcohol isn't on the scene, and people are just passing joints, those awful things that happen when alcohol is present tend not to happen at all.

If only it were that clear. An intervention by someone intoxicated can also be considered unreliable.

They need the equivalent of a sober "designated driver."

"...encouraging bystanders to step in if a pairing-off seems to be turning sour or violent."

This takes a lot of courage and it requires someone else to be paying attention have the presence of mind to notice. Ultimately, though, this is the only solution to the problem. The recent publicity regarding the problem is useful in that it sets the stage for such an intervention. We need to look out for each other... take care of those who might not realize they are in danger.

It seems at odds with the culture conservatives want to impose on America, but it's nice to see RD taking a modest step in the right direction.
